title.narrative: UN Habitat Rehab. Ec. Infrastructure Mogadishu

description.narrative: Generate sustainable employment opportunities and improve livelihoods through rehabilitation/upgrading of public market spaces in Mogadishu.

20 år av inbördeskrig har lämnat mycket av Mogadishu ekonomiska infrastruktur antingen förstörd eller allvarligt skadad. Pågående otrygghet i staden samt en process av snabb informell urbaniseringen utgör svåra påfrestningar på Mogadishus ekonomiska infrastruktur. Urbana samhällstjänster saknas och arbetslösheten är bland de högsta i världen. Det fattiga folkflertalets försörjningsmöjligheter och tillgångar har allvarligt urholkas och investeringar i de produktiva sektorerna är fortfarande begränsade. Detta projekt angriper bristen på en systematisk utveckling av urban ekonomisk infrastruktur, samt avsaknaden av lokal kapacitet för att effektivt kunna hantera och koordinera en sådan utveckling.
Projektet är tänkt att uppgradera offentliga marknadsplatser i Mogadishu och därigenom skapa ett ekonomisk nav som genererar ökade sysselsättningsmöjligheter. Prioritet kommer ges till fattiga i Mogadishu, kvinnor, ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning. Projektet kommer därtill att utveckla en förbättrad modell för ledning av urban ekonomisk infrastruktur genom både fysisk förbättring av offentliga marknadsutrymmen och genom stärkt kapacitet hos lokala myndigheter, marknadsförsäljare och andra berörda aktörer. Projektet bygger på erfarenheter från liknande projekt som Habitat har genomfört i Somalia.

The objective of the project is to Create short and long-term employment and improve livelihoods for poor women and med through rehabilitation/upgrading of key economic infrastructure in Mogadishu, primarily markets.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The ‘Job Creation through Public Market Rehabilitation’ project has been instrumental to generating sustainable employment opportunities for the communities in Mogadishu laying the foundation upon which other partners can build. R1: Upgraded public space and increased access to one urban public trade/ market place - Following much discussion and challenges in securing suitable land, assessments conducted under result 5 revealed that that the construction of the outdoor market stalls would be most suitable next to the main Nagaad meat market hall in Karaan district. The appointment of a new Director for the Market Department with a stronger vision for the potential of markets in the city was critical to commence with construction of the market stalls. In collaboration with the new BRA Market Department director, the District Commissioner and BRA engineers, the implementing partner (CESVI) and UN-Habitat completed the detailed design for new 64 market stalls at Nagaad public market. R2: Chain of economic activities stimulated and increased access to sustainable livelihoods and employment opportunities for the urban poor and other vulnerable groups, including women, youth, IDPs and persons with disabilities The construction of 64 market stalls at Nagaad Market is a substantial contributor towards cultivating economic activities for the local community through creating the space for vulnerable segments of the community to achieve livelihood opportunities. Over 64 direct livelihood opportunities where created through the construction of the Nagaad outdoor market stalls. A transparent selection process for the vendors guided and ensured that increased access to sustainable livelihoods was accorded to vulnerable women and IDPs within the community. Linking with the Youth Employment Programme (YES ), two outdoor stalls were specifically allocated for youth seeking to cultivate economic opportunities in particular, in employing the construction training they received through the YES Shaqyeso programme by establishing shops, which they can use to sell their services to the wider public. Further economic activities were stimulated through the use of local construction companies to construct the outdoor market stalls. A total number of 2,850 work days has been generated for 30 unskilled 8 skilled labors generating employment in the construction sector. In addition to the positive economic impacts generated in the community, it is important to note the wider economic activities stimulated across the city. The collection of taxes at markets across Mogadishu are integral to the revenue generated by the local administration with the Market Department serving as the third largest source of revenue for the regional administration collecting about $626,000USD from only eleven of the markets it has consistently managed over the first six months of 2016. R3: Three Market Management structures established and capacitated to secure sustainable and effective management and maintenance of the markets and increase employment opportunities and job security for the future To this end, the establishment of market management structures has been essential in the rehabilitated markets of Ansalooti, Sinay and in the Handicraft Centre. Since their foundation, the management structures have been operating from strength to strength as they meet the challenges of the markets in which they manage. Since it’s opening the management structures at Sinay have been able to operate efficiently, using the translated by-laws developed within the framework of this programme, to guide their management operations. Even stronger in their capacity is the Handicraft Centre who has been able to form a functioning cooperative underpinned by the governance mechanisms established in the by-laws. Through continuous guidance on the implementation of by-laws and support, the management structure of the Handicraft Centre has been able to work together to develop and bolster a marketing strategy that would market their good to the wider community. Through the strong guidance of a female elected Chairperson, their enhanced management capacity, accountability and transparency, can be observed in their shared management of a shop in the bustling street of via Romana in Mogadishu. Displaying all the crafts from all the vendors, the shop has not only been critical to enhancing their profits but it has been foundational in honing and developing their marketing skills as a cooperative. R4: Improved capacities in, and quality of, Mogadishu’s construction sector The project has been designed as a training programme for Banadir Regional Administration, in particular for the Urban Planning and Engineering departments. BRA engineers, technicians and planners have been trained on the job in a) conducting technical market assessments, b) designing market stalls that meet the needs of the vendors, c) conducting community consultations and participatory planning workshops, d) tender expression and evaluation and e) construction works supervision.Physical works have been supervised and controlled regularly and jointly by UN-Habitat, CESVI and BRA engineers. All works have been signed off by BRA engineers. The technical hand-over has been conducted on 24th April 2016 after completion of all physical work. UN-Habitat national and international engineers have increased the capacity of BRA engineers, technicians and planners over the course of the implementation of the physical works.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
